block.p: Japan's automakers, known for quality, hate to show fallibility. But Mitsubishi Motors finally had to admit that since 1977 it had concealed complaints about problems like faulty fuel tanks and brakes. The flaws do not seem to have caused serious accidents, but the company, which recently allied itself with DaimlerChrysler, didn't take them lightly, quickly recalling 88,000 cars and trucks, on top of a recall of 532,000 a month ago. And though Mitsubishi's president, Katsuhiko Kawasoe, did not resign, he did bow deeply in apology to the transportation minister.
